Geography: Country of Origin Egypt, Upper Egypt; Thebes, Karnak
Description: This lion-headed figure represents the goddess Sakhmet, whose name means "the powerful one." Sakhmet was goddess of war, violent storms, and pestilence. When she was appeased, her powers of destruction could be used to protect, and in this aspect she became a goddess of healing.
Provenance: Taken to England in the early 1800s by Belzoni and D'Athanasi who were working for Henry Salt
exhibited in the recesses of Waterloo Bridge, 1833
Collection of John Lee of Hartwell House
purchased by the Museum from Lord Amherst, 1915.
